title: 107_hr1397
content:
The "Youth Violence Prevention Act of 2001" includes provisions for expanding instant gun check capabilities, such as developing or expanding a State instant criminal background check system. It also aims to improve criminal justice records. Section 509 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to increase the percentage to 6%. It also includes provisions for developing or expanding a State instant criminal background check system with limited access for firearm purchasers. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to allow the transfer of firearms by a person who is not a licensed dealer, with the purchaser's authorization. TITLE II--NONREFUNDABLE CREDIT FOR PURCHASE OF SAFE STORAGE DEVICES FOR FIREARMS

SEC. 201. NONREFUNDABLE CREDIT FOR PURCHASE OF SAFE STORAGE DEVICES FOR FIREARMS. This section introduces a nonrefundable credit for the purchase of safe storage devices for firearms under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax code allows a credit for qualified firearm safe storage device expenses up to $250 per year per individual. Qualified expenses include trigger locks, secure cabinets, or other safety devices used solely for firearm storage. The tax code allows a credit for qualified firearm safe storage device expenses up to $250 per year per individual, including trigger locks, secure cabinets, or other safety devices used solely for firearm storage. The term 'firearm' is defined in section 921(a)(3) of title 18, United States Code. Title III of the tax code mandates the purchase of safe storage devices for firearms, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2000. Additionally, it prohibits the manufacture of handguns without child safety locks. Title III of the tax code requires the purchase of safe storage devices for firearms after December 31, 2000. It also prohibits manufacturing handguns without child safety locks attached, imposing a $5,000 fine for violations. The child safety lock must prevent the firearm from being discharged. Judicial review can be sought within 60 days of receiving a fine notice from the Secretary. The section allows for judicial review of the Secretary's decision in district court, excluding governmental entities. Key terms are defined as per section 921(a) of title 18, United States Code. TITLE IV--CHILD FIREARM ACCESS PREVENTION

SEC. 401. CHILDREN AND FIREARMS SAFETY. Prohibition Against Giving Juveniles Access to Certain Firearms: Defines juvenile as under 18 years. Prohibits keeping loaded or unloaded firearms in premises under custody if affecting interstate commerce, unless exceptions apply. Prohibition against giving juveniles access to firearms without secure storage. If a juvenile gains access and causes harm, imprisonment up to 1 year, fine up to $10,000, or both. Exceptions for secure gun storage, peace officers, and military personnel. The text chunk discusses exceptions to the prohibition of giving juveniles access to firearms without secure storage, including situations where the juvenile obtains the firearm during official duties, in self-defense, with no expectation of juveniles present, or as a result of unlawful entry. Additionally, it mentions the role of licensed firearms dealers in ensuring compliance with the law. The Secretary must include section 922(z) on the form for firearm transfers. State laws preventing child access to firearms are not preempted by this section.
